Copy to Chuck
A10 Tuesday, June 17, 1997 ..
SMOKE UNDER FIRE
Richmond Traes Dispatch
GWirismør Teiwz From:HUNTON & WILLIAMS
Ex-research director is said to plead Fifth again
. ..
BY CHIP JONES
THIES DISPATCH STAME WRITER
The former director of Philip Morris USA's Richmond research center exercised his right against self-incrimi- nation yesterday during pretrial questioning by lawyers from Minnesota and Pennsylvania, according to informed sources.
Dr. Thomas S. Osdere asserted his Fifth Amendment privilege during the morning sessiza at the Richmond law firm. Hunton & Williams, sources said
The retired Philip Morris vice president took the same position in mid-May when questioned by lawyers repre- number of lawsuits brought against the Richmond area's
senting the state of Texas.
Court papers in that case revealed that Osdene also has sought immunity from federal prosecution.
Osdene, who worked at Philip Morris for nearly 30 ; Osdene's' personal files that Philip Morris turned over years, is believed to be the first tobacco executive to daring pretrial discovery last year. plead the Fifth rather than answer questions about smok- ing and health research conducted from the 1960s through the 1990s at Philip Morris.
Osdene, 69, declined to comment'when reached at his Fan District home yesterday.
Osdene, a cancer researcher who became Philip Mor- ris' top scientist, has emerged as a central figure in a they tried to compel Philip Morris and other cigarette
largest private employer.
.Lawyers representing the state of Minnesota have introduced an undated, ussigned handwritten memo from
The mesmo includes the direction that "if important letters or documents have to be sent, please send them to home, where I will act on them and destroy." A brief filed by the state's attorneys said the document "appears to be" in Osdene's handwriting.
The note was introduced By Minnesota's lawyers.as Despite the favorable ruling for the tobacco industry. lawyers in the Pennsylvania suit continue to prepare for trial this fall - including yesterday's attempt to question companies to provide more detailed reponses to allega- Osdene, sources said.
tions that they have destroyed sensitive research work. Philip Morris' lawyers have vigorously denied- that charge.
Yesterday's hearing also included legal counsel for a class-action lawsuit brought against the tobacco industry in federal court in Philadelphia.
On June 4, U.S. District Judge Clarence Newcomer denied class-action status in the Pennsylvania suit, the second such ruling in recent wedrs.
